questions.text: Superantigen causes:
questions.solution:
Superantigens are a class of antigens that cause the activation of a large number of T cells by cross-linking the T-cell receptor (TCR) with the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) molecules, bypassing the normal antigen processing and presenting mechanisms. This results in the polyclonal activation of T cells and subsequent stimulation of B cells.

Superantigens

  • Act on Vβ region of TCR (T cell receptor)
  • Dont require antigen presentation by macrophage, directly stimulate non specific T cells
  • Leads to massive release of cytokines & polyclonal B cell activation

Example:

  • Staphyloccal toxin- TSST, Exfoliative toxin, Enterotoxins.
  • Streptococcal toxin- Str pyrogenic exotoxin A, B, C
  • Mycoplasma arthritidis
  • Yersinia enterocolitica.
  • M.tuberculosis
  • Viral superantigens - EBV, CMV, HIV and Rabies nucleocapsid
  • Fungal superantigens- Malassezia furfur

Key Takeaway: Superantigens bypass normal antigen presentation processes, leading to widespread immune activation.

questions.text: Which part of bacteria is mostly antigenic? (NEET Pattern Based)
questions.solution:
Proteins are generally the most antigenic components of bacteria because they can induce a robust immune response due to their complex structures and diversity. Carbohydrates and lipids can also be antigenic but are less so compared to proteins.

Key Takeaway: Bacterial proteins are the primary source of antigenicity in bacterial infections.

questions.text: T independent antigen acts through:
questions.solution:
T-independent antigens can stimulate B cells directly without the need for T-cell help. These antigens are typically polysaccharides or repetitive structures that can cross-link B cell receptors, leading to B cell activation and antibody production.

Key Takeaway: T-independent antigens activate B cells directly, bypassing the need for T helper cells.

questions.text: Superantigens are produced by all the following pathogens, except:
questions.solution:
Superantigens are produced by certain bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus and are involved in causing conditions like toxic shock syndrome. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens. Rabies virus and HIV are not known for producing superantigens; rather, they have different mechanisms of immune system manipulation.

Example:

  • Staphyloccal toxin- TSST, Exfoliative toxin, Enterotoxins.
  • Streptococcal toxin- Str pyrogenic exotoxin A, B, C
  • Mycoplasma arthritidis
  • Yersinia enterocolitica.
  • M.tuberculosis
  • Viral superantigens – EBV, CMV, HIV and Rabies nucleocapsid
  • Fungal superantigens- Malassezia furfur

Key Takeaway: Enterococcus faecalis is not a producer of superantigens, unlike Staphylococcus aureus, which is a common superantigen producer.

choices.text: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules
Binds to the beta chain of TCR stimulating T cell activation
Binds to the CD4 + molecule causing T cell activation
Is presented by macrophages to a larger-than-normal number of T helper CD4 + lymphocytes

questions.text: A super antigen is a bacterial product that:
questions.solution:
Superantigens bind to the beta chain of the T-cell receptor (TCR) and the MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells. This non-specific binding leads to excessive T cell activation and cytokine release.

Key Takeaway: Superantigens bypass normal antigen processing and stimulate T cell activation through non-specific interactions.

questions.text: Superantigens are:
questions.solution:
Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome toxin is a well-known superantigen produced by Staphylococcus aureus. Other options like erythrotoxin, Clostridium difficile toxin, and cholera toxin are not superantigens.

Key Takeaway: The Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome toxin is a classic example of a superantigen.

choices.text: Does not require stimulation by T cells

questions.text: All of the following statements about carbohydrate antigen are true except:
questions.solution:
Carbohydrate antigens generally have lower immunogenicity and do not induce a memory response as effectively as protein antigens. They can cause polyclonal B cell stimulation and do not require T cell help for stimulation.

Key Takeaway: Carbohydrate antigens typically do not induce a memory response and have lower immunogenicity compared to proteins.

questions.text: The protection against smallpox by previous infection with cowpox represents:
questions.solution:
The protection against smallpox due to previous infection with cowpox is an example of antigenic cross-reactivity, where the immune system responds to similar antigens found in both cowpox and smallpox viruses.

Key Takeaway: Antigenic cross-reactivity can provide protection against related pathogens due to shared antigens.

choices.text: It needs carrier to induce immune response
It has no association with MHC

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about hapten? (AI 2004)
questions.solution:
Haptens are small molecules that are not immunogenic on their own. They require a carrier protein to form a complex that can be recognized by the immune system and induce an immune response.

Key Takeaway: Haptens need to be conjugated with carrier proteins to be immunogenic.

questions.text: Heterophile antibody is found in:
questions.solution:
Heterophile antibodies are typically detected in the Weil-Felix test, which is used to identify certain types of rickettsial infections. The Widal test is used for typhoid fever, and standard agglutination tests are used for various bacterial infections.

Key Takeaway: The Weil-Felix test is associated with the detection of heterophile antibodies.

questions.text: All of the following interactions occur between antigen-antibody reactions except:
questions.solution:
Antigen-antibody interactions primarily involve ionic bonds, hydrogen bonds, and Van der Waals forces. Covalent bonds are not typically involved in these interactions.

Key Takeaway: Antigen-antibody interactions are primarily mediated by non-covalent forces.

questions.text: Which antibody is primarily responsible for mucosal immunity?
questions.solution:
• IgA: This antibody is primarily found in mucosal areas, such as the gut, respiratory tract, and urogenital tract. It plays a crucial role in mucosal immunity by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces. It is present in secretions such as saliva, tears, and breast milk.
  • IgM: This antibody is primarily found in the blood and lymphatic fluid. It is the first antibody produced in response to an infection but is not involved in mucosal immunity.
  • IgG: This is the most abundant antibody in the blood and extracellular fluid, providing systemic protection but not specifically targeting mucosal areas.
  • IgE: This antibody is involved in allergic reactions and defense against parasitic infections, not mucosal immunity.

Key Takeaway: IgA is essential for mucosal immunity, protecting the body's entry points against infections.

questions.text: Which antibody class is the most effective at activating the classical complement pathway?
questions.solution:
• IgG: This class of antibodies is highly effective at activating the classical complement pathway. It binds to antigens and triggers a series of complement activation steps that lead to pathogen destruction.(EXCEPT IgG4)
  • IgA: Primarily involved in mucosal immunity and does not activate the complement system efficiently.
  • IgD: This antibody is mainly found on the surface of immature B cells and does not significantly activate the complement pathway.
  • IgE: This antibody is involved in allergic reactions and does not play a major role in complement activation.

Key Takeaway: IgG is crucial for complement activation and pathogen elimination through the classical pathway.

questions.text: Which antibody is primarily responsible for mucosal immunity?
questions.solution:
• IgA: This antibody is primarily found in mucosal areas, such as the gut, respiratory tract, and urogenital tract. It plays a crucial role in mucosal immunity by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces. It is present in secretions such as saliva, tears, and breast milk.
  • IgM: This antibody is primarily found in the blood and lymphatic fluid. It is the first antibody produced in response to an infection but is not involved in mucosal immunity.
  • IgG: This is the most abundant antibody in the blood and extracellular fluid, providing systemic protection but not specifically targeting mucosal areas.
  • IgE: This antibody is involved in allergic reactions and defense against parasitic infections, not mucosal immunity.

Key Takeaway: IgA is essential for mucosal immunity, protecting the body's entry points against infections.

questions.text: Which antibody is the primary mediator of allergic reactions?
questions.solution:
• IgE: This antibody is central to allergic reactions. It binds to allergens and triggers mast cells and basophils to release histamine and other inflammatory mediators, leading to allergic symptoms such as itching, swelling, and redness.
  • IgM: This antibody is involved in the initial response to infections and does not mediate allergic reactions.
  • IgG: While it can be involved in some allergic responses, IgE is the primary mediator of allergic reactions.
  • IgA: This antibody protects mucosal surfaces but does not mediate allergic responses.

Key Takeaway: IgE is key in mediating allergic reactions by interacting with allergens and triggering inflammatory responses.

questions.text: Which antibody class is known for its role in the initial response to infections?
questions.solution:
• IgM: This is the first antibody produced in response to an infection and is primarily found in the blood and lymphatic fluid. It is effective in forming antigen-antibody complexes and initiating the complement cascade, which helps eliminate pathogens early in the infection.
  • IgA: While important for mucosal immunity, it is not the primary antibody involved in the initial response to infections.
  • IgD: Found mainly on B cell surfaces and does not play a significant role in the initial immune response.
  • IgG: Although crucial for long-term immunity, it is not the primary antibody produced during the initial response to infections.

Key Takeaway: IgM is essential for the early response to infections, providing initial defense and aiding in the activation of the immune system.

questions.text: Examine the image of an antibody structure provided below. Which region of the antibody binds to the antigen?
questions.solution:
• Fab Region: The Fab (Fragment antigen-binding) region is the part of the antibody that binds to the specific antigen. It contains the variable regions of both heavy and light chains that are responsible for antigen specificity.
  • Fc Region: This is the constant region that interacts with cell receptors and complements but does not bind directly to the antigen.
  • Hinge Region: This provides flexibility to the antibody but is not directly involved in antigen binding.
  • Variable Region: While crucial for antigen binding, it is not a distinct part like the Fab region.

Key Takeaway: The Fab region is where antigen binding occurs, crucial for the antibody’s specificity.

choices.text: Delayed-type T-cell activation and tissue damage
Immediate reaction mediated by IgE and histamine release
Complement activation and immune complex deposition

questions.text: Which of the following features is typically associated with this type of hypersensitivity 1 reaction?
questions.solution:
• Hypersensitivity Type I: Also known as immediate or anaphylactic hypersensitivity. It is mediated by IgE antibodies bound to mast cells and basophils. Upon re-exposure to the allergen, these cells release histamine and other mediators, leading to rapid allergic reactions such as anaphylaxis or hay fever.
  • Delayed-Type T-Cell Activation: This is associated with hypersensitivity type IV.
  • Complement Activation: Associated with hypersensitivity types II and III.
  • Antibody-Mediated Cytotoxicity: This involves IgG and is related to hypersensitivity type II.

Key Takeaway: Hypersensitivity type I is characterized by an immediate reaction involving IgE antibodies and histamine release.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
• Option C) Type III Hypersensitivity: Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complex deposition, leading to inflammation and tissue damage. It is seen in diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, not typically associated with urticaria.
  • A) Type I Hypersensitivity: Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate allergic reaction mediated by IgE antibodies. Common manifestations include anaphylaxis, urticaria, and angioedema, typically triggered by allergens like peanuts, insect stings, or pollen.
  • Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity: Type II hypersensitivity involves antibody-mediated cytotoxicity, where IgG or IgM antibodies target cells. This reaction is seen in conditions such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia or Rh incompatibility, and it does not typically
  • Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity: Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction mediated by T cells, often occurring 48-72 hours after exposure to an antigen. It is seen in contact dermatitis or tuberculin skin tests but does not present with immediate urticaria after allergen exposure.

Key Takeaway:

  • Mechanism: Immune complex formation and deposition.
  • Mediators: IgG or IgM antibodies.
  • Common Conditions: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), rheumatoid arthritis, serum sickness, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • Target Tissues: Blood vessels (vasculitis), kidneys (glomerulonephritis), joints (arthritis).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is an example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
• Option A) Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome is primarily a Type II hypersensitivity reaction where antibodies target the basement membrane of the lungs and kidneys, leading to tissue damage.
  • Option B) Serum sickness: Serum sickness is a classic example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction, where immune complexes form in response to injected foreign proteins (like antiserum) and deposit in tissues, causing fever, rash, and joint pain.
  • Option C) Tuberculosis skin test: The tuberculosis (TB) skin test is an example of a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, where T cells mediate a delayed response to injected tuberculin antigen.
  • Option D) Myasthenia gravis: Myasthenia gravis is a Type II hypersensitivity reaction where antibodies block acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Serum sickness is an example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by the formation of immune complexes that deposit in tissues and cause systemic symptoms. This contrasts with Type II hypersensitivity conditions like Goodpasture syndrome and Myasthenia gravis, and Type IV reactions like the tuberculosis skin test.
